sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews Tonight. Here are your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Russia strikes key for the first time in weeks as the UK announces it is sending new rocket launcher systems to Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Could the party be over for Boris Johnson?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The British Prime Minister faces a vote of confidence which would force him to step down if he loses.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: of confidence which would force him to step down if he loses. Ryanair faces backlash for forcing South African passengers to fill out a test in Afrikaans.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We'll have the story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And German car maker Mercedes-Benz announces it is recalling nearly one million vehicles over potential problems with their braking systems.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: I'm Helena Humphrey.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Good to have you with us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Russian President Vladimir Putin has warned that Moscow will look to attack new targets following missile strikes on Ukraine's capital, Kiev.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Ukrainian officials say that Moscow launched five cruise missiles towards the city, the first attack on the area in over a month.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Well, the country's atomic operator warned of a possible nuclear disaster after one cruise missile flew close to a nuclear plant south of the city.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The UK Defence Ministry says the attack was likely an attempt to disrupt Western arms shipments to Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The governor of Luhansk claims that Ukrainian forces have regained half of Severodonetsk.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Fierce fighting has taken place in the city. Some 15,000 civilians are still sheltering in the area. On Monday, President Zelensky said that his soldiers in Severodonetsk are holding their ground but did warn that the Russians are more numerous and more powerful. Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov has been forced to cancel his visit to the Serbian

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: capital Belgrade after his plane was blocked from entering the airspace of Serbia's surrounding cities, countries excuse me.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Lavrov said the decision was outrageous and described the move as an act of hostility by NATO.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The decisions that were taken by some members of NATO and the decisions that prevented the implementation of the visit of the Russian Foreign Minister to Serbia are certainly unthinkable.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: I understand the interest you show in our assessment of these outrageous actions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: There was a deprivation of the right of the sovereign state to carry out foreign policy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Well, our correspondent Galina Polonskaya is covering this story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We can go straight over to her now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Good evening to you, Galina. Good to see you. Some pretty strong words there from Lavrov in response to that closing of airspace, preventing him from landing in Belgrade. So what now? Any hints of Russian retaliation?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Sergei Lavrov said that at this point Russia will not retaliate, not to harm the relations, as I said, between the people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But he surely stressed one thing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: He said that no one will be able to destroy the relations between Russia and Serbia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And we have indeed heard very, very strong words from him he condemned the decision of Bulgaria North Macedonia Montenegro to ban his flight to pass to Serbia said that it was unthinkable unprecedented and outrageous and surely stressed that it was the NATO and the EU to blame he said that the Brussels policy in Ukraine and the Balkans was the same and promised that nothing will stand in the way between Russia and Serbia, that the Serbian foreign minister was invited to Russia and that this visit might happen very soon.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The Kremlin has also commented what has happened and called those actions to ban the flight of Russia's foreign minister hostile. We've also heard today from Lavrov with regards to the delivery of those longer range missiles coming from the UK now as well as from the United States. We know that Putin said in response to that that he would increase his list of targets. Do we know where those targets are?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: increase his list of targets. Do we know where those targets are. Well Vladimir Putin just said that Russia will draw appropriate conclusions that it will use its arms to strike. I quoted those targets which Russian forces has not yet been hitting. He did not precise what are those targets where they are located. But Sergei Lavrov gave more explanations. He said, and I quote, the longer the range of the missiles that the West supplies to Kyiv will be, the further we will push the Nazis away from the territories where the threat to Russia comes from. And we have also heard some comments that I find important from the head of Russia's defense committee in the state Duma, the lower house of Russian parliament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: He said that Russia may strike at the infrastructure and state institutions in Ukraine in case of deliveries of long-range missiles.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And he also said that it was not excluded that peacekeepers from the Collective Security Treaty Organization might be used at the territories in Ukraine controlled by Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: All right, Galina Polonskaya, our correspondent as ever.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Galina, good to talk to you. Thanks for that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: I want to get the view of Brad Bowman now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: He is the senior director of the Center on Military and Political Power at the Foundation for Defense of Democracies. He's also a former Black Hawk helicopter pilot himself. Brad, as always, great to have you on the program. As we were just discussing, the UK has now joined the United States in sending over those rocket launches. There's been so much about this really since the beginning of the war discussing whether these kinds of weapons would be appropriate. Something's changed here. What do you think that calculation was.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Thanks for the opportunity to join you. Thanks for the question. I think what has changed is the nature of the combat has evolved after Putin bit off more than he could chew if you will and going for Kiev and launching armored columns not supported by artillery or infantry, we've seen them kind of downsize their ambitions and really just focus on the Donbass region, Donetsk and Luhansk.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And that region has a different topography that is more conducive to artillery warfare.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So we're seeing an artillery duel in that region that is brutal.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We've seen the Russians making incremental gains and we see in many cases the Ukrainians are outranged and outgunned. And so they've been asking for these longer range artillery systems for quite some time. And now the U.S. announced last week they would be providing the high mobility artillery rocket systems or high Mars which will roughly double the range over the towed artillery the US had already provided. And now the British are saying that they will want to provide also as you as your team has reported the multiple launch rocket system of that in the HIMARS will roughly double the range that the Ukrainians have in terms of artillery infantry inventory. Talking about that then talking about doubling the range. I mean talking about that then talking about doubling the range I mean these weapons have been characterized as attack weapons as opposed to defensive ones and Putin has been saying that if they come from countries like the UK like the US he's been trying to couch that as saying these countries then are directly involved so do you think that could potentially lead from Russia's side to an escalation at this moment? Is this a pivotal moment in this conflict? Well, you know, Putin can always escalate, but let's remember where we are. This is the largest invasion in Europe since World War II.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: You know, we hear Foreign Minister Lavrov talking about the sovereignty of Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Excuse me? What about the sovereignty of Ukraine. Right. This is this is really Russian gall at its at its we've long come to see. You know Ukraine has a right to defend itself. The MLS system the multiple launch rocket system the high MR systems that the U.S. are providing. These are going to be targeting the tens of thousands of invading Russian forces in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: For Putin to suggest that this is a threat to Russia in any way is ridiculous, and I think should be seen as such.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Briefly, if you don't mind, Brad, in terms of having these weapons, putting them into the equation, how do they change things on the ground?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Could we see a recalibration from the Ukrainians, or do you predict instead that the Russians might just go even harder? The primary benefit of these weapons is they increase the range of Ukrainian forces. They provide them additional precision, more agility and mobility and more survivability. And all of those things will help impact the balance of power between the Russian Ukrainian forces as Ukraine fights this unprovoked invasion and defends their homes. All right Brad Bowman senior director of the Center on Military and Political Power at the Foundation for Defense of Democracies. Pleasure to talk to you. Thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is facing a confidence vote following a rebellion within

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: the ranks of his own party. Now, enough Conservative MPs have submitted letters of doubt over Johnson's leadership to trigger a ballot that will decide his future as Prime Minister. Neil O'Reilly has more now on the story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: A day of destiny for Boris Johnson. After months of deepening scandals and growing discontent among his party, the British Prime Minister is to face a vote of confidence from Conservative MPs today. It could lead to him stepping down as PM. The vote was triggered after the head of the group representing Tory MPs received 54 letters from disgruntled parliamentary colleagues.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The threshold of 15% of the parliamentary party seeking a vote of confidence in the Prime Minister has been passed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Therefore, a vote of confidence will take place within the rules of the 1922 committee.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: That vote will take place this evening in the House of Commons between 6 and 8 o'clock.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And we will announce the result shortly thereafter.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: will announce the result shortly thereafter. Boris Johnson's popularity has plummeted since revelations of parties in Downing Street that broke lockdown rules, one of which resulted in a fine for the Prime Minister. If he loses the confidence vote, Johnson will face a leadership challenge. His days as UK leader could be numbered. All right, well, I'm glad now to bring in Lila

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Howson-Smith. She is the former special advisor to both Boris Johnson and the former British Prime Minister, Theresa May. Great to see you. Thanks for taking the time. Let's not beat around the bush on this one. Can he survive?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So I think there's a number of questions here, really. I guess first, it's whether the inducements work. So whether his kind of carrot and stick methods can really kind of bring out a result in terms of turning around those wavering Conservative MPs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So we've heard today that he's been offering some promotions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So that's kind of clear the incentive.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But he's also been talking about an early general election, which is really kind of quite unappealing to certain MPs that were elected back in 2019. So it's the question of whether that kind of combination can really bring on side those wavering Conservative MPs, those MPs that maybe don't support Boris or aren't in ministerial positions whose support can't necessarily be counted on. That absolutely is the question or the questions. But what about your prediction? Do you think he can survive? So I think it's going to be closer than it looks. Definitely, I don't think today has gone as well as number 10 would have wanted. When I was working for Theresa May in the last leadership election, she had a number of more endorsements by this stage. So I think they've been coming in a bit slower. But that said, the important thing to remember is that Boris Johnson automatically has sort of about 160 MPs on side, so nearly half the Conservative Party on side, because they fundamentally work for him.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: They are ministers or junior kind of parliamentary undersecretaries. So the key thing is here, can Boris Johnson make up that number through the backbenchers?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And I think it looks extremely likely that he will.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But that margin, sort of how big that majority is, will be really important to look at, particularly when you're thinking about how he survives kind of going forward and whether there continues to be that pressure on him and that drip-drip effect that we've seen in recent weeks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: You said things might not have been going quite how he would have liked today when you compare that to Theresa May and when she faced this vote I mean it certainly came about very quickly we've got MPs barely back from the Platinum Jubilee celebrations and now this vote as a former special adviser do you think that was part of the strategy just to kind of go for it very quickly?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Yeah, absolutely. I think Boris Johnson would have thought that kind of time, a short period of time is the best way to kind of get MPs on side, but also to ensure those rebels, those people that are clearly against him, don't have much time to organise, don't have much time to kind of galvanise support. I also think it's worth mentioning here that there aren't really that many kind of credible or clear alternatives in terms of other potential leadership rivals. Obviously, the Chancellor, Rishi Sunak, has often been kind of the person that Boris Johnson was seen to be up against previously. And he's really seen quite a lot of knockbacks in recent months and weeks. So Boris Johnson, there's no clear successor, which I think is very helpful to him alongside with that kind of short time frame that you mentioned. All right, Lila Houston-Smith, a former special advisor to both Boris Johnson and Theresa May. Thanks for being on the programme. Ryanair has been accused of racism after announcing

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: that citizens in South Africa will be forced to take a test in Afrikaans before flying to Europe. Let's head over to the cube now for more on this story. Matthew it has generated an awful lot of talk online what is going on? Well Helena, Ryanair who are of course one of Europe's largest airlines say that this is necessary to combat the high prevalence of fake South African passports. The company is now going to be requiring South African citizens to fill out what it says is a simple general knowledge questionnaire in Afrikaans.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: This before they are allowed to fly to the United Kingdom on Ryanair flights from other parts of Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Now the questions on this test are going to be things like who is South Africa's current president and what is the country's international dialing code. And Ryanair says that if people aren't able to fill out this test they won't be allowed to fly but will be given a full refund but the company has been widely criticized and accused of racial discrimination now the reason for this is that South Africa has 11 official languages and Afrikaans is just the third most widely spoken in the country after Zulu and Xhosa. According to a 2011 census just over 13% of South African citizens spoke Afrikaans as a first language and it's also been viewed as the language of the oppressor given Afrikaans was forced on the country's black population during the era of apartheid. So as you can imagine, there's a lot of criticism online.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Many people in the country say that they are disgusted by what they describe as highly insensitive racial profiling.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And a German MP, Fabio De Massi, says that this new policy is like forcing Dutch or British tourists to take a test about apartheid in Xhosa before they are allowed to enter Cape Town.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And it's also important to note Helena that the United Kingdom's High Commission in South Africa says that this is not an official government policy. This controversial Afrikaans test, general knowledge questionnaire, it seems to have come directly from Ryanair itself.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Well Matthew, a very remarkable controversial story as you say. Thanks for bringing it to us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Mercedes-Benz has announced the immediate recall of nearly one million cars because of potential

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: problems with their braking system now the german luxury car maker says it'll contact owners of vehicles built between 2004 and 2015. almost 1 million vehicles are affected including 70 000 in germany alone now the models are from the ML and GL series of SUVs and R-class luxury minivans. At least 50 people have been killed, including children, after gunmen opened fire at a Catholic church in southeastern Nigeria. Attackers shot inside the church in the town of Oul during Sunday mass while other gunmen waited outside for those trying to flee. Local authorities say that the gunmen escaped. No group has claimed responsibility for the massacre. Wales has secured its place at the 2022 World Cup with a 1-0 win over Ukraine

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: in their qualifier playoff final. An own goal by Ukraine's Andrii Yermolenko sealed the victory for the hosts in Cardiff and our sports editor Andy Rabini joins me to discuss what was a gripping game. An intensely emotional event I think as well it's fair to say Andy. The decisive goal coming perhaps in the cruelest of ways as well. So what does this mean then for Wales going forward. Well their fans will be delighted with this result. An overwhelming majority of them have never seen Wales at a World Cup tournament. Now we've been associating Wales with this team that comes so close but stumbles at the final hurdle. We saw this in 77, 85, 93 but we have seen a different Wales national team in recent years. They qualified for Euro 2016 ending a 58 year wait for a major tournament then they qualified for 2020 it was a tough game though Gareth Belsman and it was a difficult situation there against a Ukraine very resilient team obviously the the condition back home galvanized the the players we saw it against Scotland a few days ago and we saw it against Wales last night almost against the run of play though Wales managed to score thanks to a Yarmolenko own goal.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: But it was a good performance from Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: 1-0 was the final score.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: It could have been way more, but some good performances there from the goalkeepers, especially Hennessy with a man-of-the-match performance to keep a clean sheet.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: When you talk about this game, you have to mention the supporters, though.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: They were absolutely fantastic. You know that football is often vilified and we saw these events at Saint Denis even the French Interior Minister started blaming the fans and then backtracked and said it was a due to fake tickets. The thing is football can probably bring the worst out of people because it's such a popular sport but in most cases bring the best out of people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: We saw this last night. These fans were great. 100 refugees were given free tickets by the Football Association of Wales and now these fans will probably enjoy the Qatar World Cup. They're in the same group as England, the United States and Iran. A busy Sunday of sport as well. We've got Rafa Nadal winning the French Open at Roland Garros. But did the world number four give us any clues into next events what's next for him his future well his press conference was not reassuring if you're in a doubt fan he said with the circumstances I can't and don't want to keep going I mean first things first what Nadal has done is remarkable absolutely surreal for any player it's a feature in 14 French Opens is outstanding.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: He's actually won 14 of them, 22 Grand Slams.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: That's two more than his greatest rivals, Federer and Novak Djokovic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And what makes this even more incredible is that he's done this through injury.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: He was suffering from chronic foot problem.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: He nearly retired last year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: He's had multiple injections throughout this tournament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: He suffers from Muller-Weiss syndrome, which is a rare degenerative condition that affects bones in the feet.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: That's why he was limping during the Italian Open, 10 days before Roland Garros actually started. In a few days' time, he'll undergo nerve-burning treatment. If this doesn't work, it means that he'll certainly miss out on Wimbledon and also there's a good chance that he'll consider surgery.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Now, when you're 36, you know that surgery, there's a bit of a time there to come back.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Will he want to do this at the age of 36 or retire before?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Only he knows, but I hope he'll stay for a few more years if he can.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And I'm sure, of course, many fans around the world wishing the same.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Our sports editor, Andy Rubini, good to talk to you. Thank you, Andy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: wishing the same. Our sports editor Andy Rubini, good to talk to you. Thank you Andy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Now as the sun rose over France's Normandy beaches on the 6th of June, a small band of brothers got together to remember D-Day as well as to pay their respects to comrades who lay down their lives to give Europe the gift of peace. Tom Hill reports now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: It took five years, five long... A dozen veterans in Normandy for D-Day, heroes who waded ashore to turn the tide of tyranny across Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: They thought they would be safe. They would be wrong.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Among that force, a 19-year-old medic, now 98, the Native American soldier said a prayer for lost friends, but also passed on a message for today's victims of war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: for lost friends but also passed on a message for today's victims of war. Ukraine is a very sad situation. I feel sorry for the people there and I don't know why this war had to come but I think the human being likes to, I think they like to fight, I don't know.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But we see this and now what's going on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: 1944 I landed on these beaches and we thought we would bring peace to the world, but it's not possible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: 156,000 soldiers from America, Britain, Canada and other countries attacked France on D-Day, storming its beaches but also landing by parachute and gliders. As each year passes, veteran numbers dwindle, but the sacrifices they made to ensure peace live on even in times of uncertainty. Tom Hill, Euronews.
